title: 5 dead in  exceptionally  strong storm in Houston
message:
5 dead in 'exceptionally' strong storm in HoustonAt least five people were killed when a powerful wind storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the "exceptionally" strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.
The statement also said President Biden had directed the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) "to coordinate Federal recovery operations in the affected areas."
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.
event_breakdown: Five people have died in a powerful wind storm that tore through Houston on Thursday night and caused major damage.

title: Corps shuts dams at Waco , Whitney to protect downstream
message:
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers on Friday halted water releases from Lake Waco and other flooded reservoirs in surrounding counties to relieve flooding far downstream in the Houston area.
Lake Waco remained 15.8 feet above its conservation pool of 462 feet above sea level after heavy rains in recent weeks.
Corps of Engineers officials at the three lakes work together to determine release rates, Lake Waco manager Mike Champagne said.
In Waco, Champagne said downstream flooding has hindered the amount of water Lake Waco can release, and it will likely be several days before the dam is opened again.
Both lakes are also Corps of Engineers flood control reservoirs that empty into tributaries of the Brazos River.
event_breakdown:
Natural Disasters Events:
1. Heavy rain in Waco and surrounding counties
2. Downstream flooding in Waco
3. High water level in Lake Waco

title: Active hurricane season could have  detrimental impact  on home insurance
message:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — The predictions for this upcoming hurricane season are serious with numerous storms predicted.
It's creating concern over what the season could do to Florida's insurance costs.
WPTV Mark Friedlander shares his thoughts on what an active hurricane season could mean for insurance costs in Florida.
"Large loss events always impact insurance markets, no matter how strong those insurance markets are," Friedlander said.
"If you have a heavy volume of loss activity during hurricane season, it's going to change the dynamics."
event_breakdown:
1. Hurricane Season Predictions for Florida: There are numerous storms predicted for the upcoming hurricane season in Florida.
2. Insurance Costs in Florida: The predictions for an active hurricane season in Florida are raising concerns about what the season could do to insurance costs.
3. Impact of Large Loss Events on Insurance Markets: Natural disaster events always impact insurance markets, no matter how strong those insurance markets are.
4. Hurricane Season in Florida: The hurricane season in Florida will heavily impact insurance costs in the state.

title: Houston storm : At least 4 killed , more than 700 , 000 without power across Texas
message:
(HOUSTON) — At least four people were killed when an “exceptionally” strong storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, according to Mayor John Whitmire.
The winds — which reached 78 mph — sounded like a freight train, Houston residents told ABC News.
Houston schools are closed on Friday and more than 770,000 customers lost power across the state.
The mayor said Houston is in “recovery mode.”“Please … stay away from downtown — it’s dangerous.
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.
event_breakdown:
* A powerful storm hit Houston.
* Winds reached 78 mph.
* At least 4 people were killed.
* Nearly 800,000 people lost power.
* Schools were closed on Friday.
* Thousands of people left the downtown area of the city.
* The Houston mayor said the city is in recovery mode.

title: Houston storm : At least five killed , more than 600 , 000 without power
message:
(HOUSTON) — At least five people were killed when a powerful storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the “exceptionally” strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.

event_breakdown:
1) A powerful storm hit Houston, causing straight-line winds to reach 100 mph in downtown Houston.
2) The storm caused  2,500 traffic lights to go out, making travel unsafe.
3) The storm injured five people and ultimately  killed at least five people, likely by falling objects or falling trees. remained without power following the storm.
4) The storm did not cause flooding, likely because the winds stopped before there was enough rain to cause flooding.
5) The storm on Thursday lasted approximately 20 minutes, and was followed by a cold front on Friday morning that brought temperatures in the 60s.
6) Whitmire described the storm as “exceptional,” but its context is more vague. The worst hurricane to hit Houston in the past twenty years was Hurricane Ike, in 2008. That storm caused at least $20 billion in damage, however, so in comparison, the five deaths caused by the storm yesterday is significantly different. The damage is similarly less.

title: Leon County estimates storm debris cleanup could take up to a month
message:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (WCTV) - Crews in Leon County began storm debris pickup Friday, a week after three tornadoes swept through the local area.
County officials believe it could take up to a month for storm debris cleanup to be completed around the capital city.
As of Friday morning, crews have picked up 10,000 cubic yards of debris which they said is about half of what was collected last year after Hurricane Idalia.
The director of Community Relations and Resilience of Leon County, Matt Cavell, said in all the years of responding to tornados and hurricanes, the county hasn’t seen damage on this scale before.

title: Afghanistan : 50 killed , dozens missing after flooding in Ghor province
message:
CNN —Fifty people were killed and dozens are missing after heavy rains and flooding in Afghanistan’s province of Ghor on Friday, according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugees.
The Ministry said in a post on X on Saturday that 2,000 homes had been completely destroyed and up to 4,000 partially destroyed by recent flooding.
Hundreds of people have been killed by flash flooding in Afghanistan over the past several weeks, according to the UN.
Areas in northern Afghanistan have been ravaged by the heavy floods, including the provinces of Ghor, Badakhshan, Baghlan, and Herat.
In April, unseasonal rainfall and floods killed more than 100 people in Afghanistan and Pakistan, according to authorities.

title: Afghanistan : 50 killed , dozens missing after flooding in Ghor province
message:
CNN —Fifty people were killed and dozens are missing after heavy rains and flooding in Afghanistan’s province of Ghor on Friday, according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugees.
The Ministry said in a post on X on Saturday that 2,000 homes had been completely destroyed and up to 4,000 partially destroyed by recent flooding.
Hundreds of people have been killed by flash flooding in Afghanistan over the past several weeks, according to the UN.
Areas in northern Afghanistan have been ravaged by the heavy floods, including the provinces of Ghor, Badakhshan, Baghlan, and Herat.
In April, unseasonal rainfall and floods killed more than 100 people in Afghanistan and Pakistan, according to authorities.
event_breakdown: Floods in Afghanistan

title: Abnormally hot summer expected for New York in latest NOAA forecast
message:
(NEXSTAR) – New predictions for the summer season, released by NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center this week, show weather is likely to heat up in almost every corner of the United States.
The forecast, which covers June, July and August, indicates nearly every U.S. state with leaning toward a hotter-than-normal summer season.
The only exception to the forecast on the continental U.S. are the Dakotas and parts of Minnesota and Iowa.
The section of the upper Midwest, shaded in white on the map below, has equal chances of a normal summer, hotter-than-average summer and a cooler-than-average summer.
The summer forecast hasn’t just grown hotter over the last month, but it’s also grown drier.
event_breakdown:
1. Heat wave summer forecast map of the United States released in 2022 from NOAA's Climate Prediction Center
2. Summer forecast's only exceptions are Dakotas and parts of Minnesota and Iowa having equal chances of normal summer (wither below or above average) temperature
3. Forecasted hotter-than-average summer season for entire continental U.S. except white sections of upper Midwest
4. Forecast released May 2022 for summer season of 2022 (June, July and August)

title: Watch :  Apocalyptic Scene Out Of Houston , Texas As Four Die Due To Severe Thunderstorms
message:
A severe storm with hurricane-force winds hit Houston on Thursday, killing at least four people, blowing windows out of high-rise buildings and leaving some thousands of homes without power.
The US National Weather Service also issued a flood watch for the Houston area from heavy rains associated with the storm.
JUST IN: Apocalyptic scenes out of Houston, Texas as severe thunderstorms sweep through the city, demolishing buildings in the downtown area.80 mph winds blew out windows in downtown Houston and knocked out power for 1 million residents.
Commissioner @LesleyBrionesTX, @houmayor @whitmire_john, @houstonpolice, and @HoustonFire are currently inspecting the damaged done downtown following the storm.
Whitmire delivered similar initial storm assessments during a brief televised news conference carried live a short time after his interview.

- The storm blew windows out of high-rise buildings

title: Fire Weather  By John Vaillant
message:
In May 2016, Fort McMurray, the hub of Canada’s oil industry and America’s biggest foreign supplier, was overrun by wildfire.
The multi-billion-dollar disaster melted vehicles, turned entire neighborhoods into firebombs, and drove 88,000 people from their homes in a single afternoon.
In his latest book, Fire Weather, bestselling author John Vaillant warns that this inferno – the wildfire equivalent of Hurricane Katrina – was not a unique event, but a shocking preview of what we must prepare for in a hotter, more flammable world.
John Vaillant is the author of the bestselling books, The Golden Spruce and The Tiger.
His debut novel, The Jaguar’s Children, was a finalist for the prestigious International Dublin Literary Award.
event_breakdown:
Fort McMurray Wildfire - 2016
The multi-billion-dollar disaster - wildfires and flooding - in May 2016 caused one of the largest evacuations in Alberta's history and the second-largest evacuation in Canada after the 2011 evacuation of Atlantic Canada. The community was devastated, with tens of thousands of homes lost.

title: 28 areas are  severely vulnerable  to flooding in Karnataka | Bengaluru News
message:
BENGALURU: Karnataka State Natural Disaster Monitoring Centre ( KSNDMC ) has identified 102 areas across the city as prone to flooding during the anticipated heavy rain over the next three days, and alerted BBMP , Bescom, National Disaster Response Force, and other civic organizations about the same.According to a report accessed by TOI, 28 of these areas are classified as severely vulnerable while 74 are moderately vulnerable.
"Rajarajeshwari Nagar and Bommanahalli zones are expected to receive very heavy rainfall, ranging from 115.6mm to 204.4mm, between May 18 and 22.
Parts of Kengeri, Hemmigepura, Anjanapura, Gottigere, and RR Nagar are likely to be severely affected," said a senior official from KSNDMC.
"These are pre-monsoon showers, and with a microclimate, the wind direction is unlikely to change significantly.
"This will increase the water-carrying capacity and prevent flooding of homes in these areas," Kishor said.

* Flooding
* Heavy rain

title: In case the need arises : How to build an emergency storm kit – Deseret News
message:
The Central North Pacific and Atlantic hurricane season lasts from June 1 to Nov. 30, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Storms occur most often in the spring and summer months, and vary in their length depending on location.
In fact, the National Weather Center has provided a list of storm risk categories, ranging from marginal to high.
The National Weather Center provided a few safety basics: stay inside, away from doors and windows; get down, to the lowest floor available; cover up; stay calm.
Maintaining an emergency kit can also be a helpful way to stay prepared for severe weather, according to the CDC.
event_breakdown:
Natural Disaster:
- Central North Pacific and Atlantic hurricane season from June 1 to November 30.
- Category risk ranking listed from Marginal to High.
- Safety procedures include staying inside, going to the lowest floor, sheltering in place, and staying calm.
- Preparing for the storm by maintaining an emergency kit.

title: Severe weather tears through the south , NWS explains storm system
message:
Severe storms swept across the south Thursday leaving a path of destruction.
While severe thunderstorms are nothing out of the ordinary this time of year, experts say it is less common to see wind speeds of 80 miles per hour or higher associated with a thunderstorm.
Dr. Jake Wiley, an associate professor of meteorology at the University of South Alabama says a mesoscale convective system is what ripped through the south Thursday night.
National Weather Service of Mobile/Pensacola Meteorologist Jack Cullen says severe thunderstorm warnings are for 60 mph winds.
When severe weather affected south Alabama on May 13th the National Weather Service reported eighty mile per hour winds in Baldwin County.

- Severe storms sweep across the south
- 80 mph winds in Baldwin County

The floods also destroyed hundreds of hectares of farm land, hundreds of bridges and killed thousands of cattle, the ministry said.

The disaster was followed by a string of summer flash floods that killed over 30 people.

title: Storm system with 100 mph winds kill 7 in greater Houston area
message:
May 18 (UPI) -- At least seven people died as a storm system with wind speeds of up to 100 mph and a tornado passed through the Houston area Thursday and threatened the Southeast.
The National Weather Service reported an EF-1 tornado with wind speeds of up to 110 mph in Cyprus, while straight-line winds were recorded with wind speeds of up to 100 mph.
The storm system also damaged several skyscrapers.
Cleaning up from the storm damage will be made more difficult with high temperatures of about 90 degrees, according to the National Weather Service.
The National Weather Service advises caution while cleaning up from the storm damage due to the extended power outage that might last for several days amid high heat and humidity.

title: Scattered storms slowly sag south Saturday afternoon
message:
ROANOKE, Va. – While Saturday doesn’t look like an all-day rain, we do have the chance for scattered showers and storms.
Low pressure nearby will allow the warm, humid air to rise after 1 or 2 p.m.
Scattered storms will then move south of I-64 and into North Carolina through about 8 p.m.
Once low pressure moves toward the East Coast, we’ll see a breeze out of the northeast.
There’s the chance that we see some sun break in the New River Valley, Highlands and Roanoke Valley late Sunday afternoon.

title: Death toll rises to 7 in storm - battered Houston - World News
message:
The death toll from destructive storms battering Houston on Thursday night has risen to at least seven, the Harris County Sheriff's Office confirmed on Friday evening.
In east Houston, a 60-year-old man who lost power in the storm went out to his truck to plug in his oxygen tank.
Two high school students were injured when their school bus was stuck during the fatal storm on Thursday, said the Houston Independent School District, the largest district in Texas and the eighth largest in the United States.
Downtown Houston hit by tornado was the center of the havoc with shattered glass from highrise buildings sprawled across streets.
Earlier this month, multiple rounds of thunderstorms caused deadly flooding across eastern Texas, including the Houston area, forcing evacuations and school closures.

title: Flash floods kill 50 in northern Afghanistan
message:
A man stands in the mud after a flash flood in Baghlan, Afghanistan, on May 11, 2024.
File Photo by Samiullah Popal/EPA-EFEMay 18 (UPI) -- Flash floods triggered by heavy rain killed 50 people Friday in Afghanistan's Ghor province, government officials said.
AdvertisementThe floods also destroyed hundreds of hectares of farm land, hundreds of bridges and killed thousands of cattle, the ministry said.
More than 100 people and over 600 animals died in April from flash floods in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
The disaster was followed by a string of summer flash floods that killed over 30 people.
event_breakdown: Flash floods killed 50 people in Afghanistan's Ghor province on Friday.https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2019/05/18/Flash-floods-kill-50-people-in-Afghanistan/9371561783594/

title: B . C . mayor urges residents to not share images of wildfire - damaged properties
message:
Fraser’s comments come after videos were posted on social media showing what appeared to be multiple homes destroyed outside Fort Nelson.
She said RCMP are on duty in Fort Nelson to protect against looting.
Evan Peck with the BC Wildfire Service said a low-pressure system brought much-needed rain on Wednesday and Thursday, along with cooler temperatures and lower humidity, making for “excellent” conditions for fire suppression efforts.
The BC Wildfire Service said the Patry Creek fire isn’t an immediate threat to the town, but conditions can change rapidly if there are strong northerly winds.
It said more than 100 wildfire service firefighters were responding to the Fort Nelson fires, as well as about 60 structure protection firefighters and 19 helicopters.
event_breakdown:
The following are the natural-disaster events mentioned in the text:

1. Multiple homes destroyed near Fort Nelson, British Columbia.
2. RCMP is on duty in Fort Nelson to protect against looting.
3. Rain, cooler temperatures and lower humidity provide ideal conditions for fire suppression efforts.
4. The Patry Creek fire poses no immediate threat to the town of Fort Nelson, but northerly winds could change that.
5. Some 100 BC Wildfire Service firefighters are responding to the Fort Nelson fires.
6. About 60 structure protection firefighters and 19 helicopters are also involved in the response to the Fort Nelson fires.

title: Flash floods kill 50 in western Afghanistan
message:
Kabul: Flash flooding has killed at least 50 people in western Afghanistan, provincial police said Saturday, a week after hundreds were washed away in the north of the country.
"Fifty residents of Ghor province were killed by the floods on Friday and a number of others are missing," Badri said.
"These terrible floods have also killed thousands of cattle...
They have destroyed hundreds of hectares of agricultural land, hundreds of bridges and culverts, and destroyed thousands of trees," he added.
From mid-April to early May, flash flooding and other floods had left about 100 people dead in 10 of Afghanistan's provinces, authorities said.
event_breakdown:
Flash flooding
Floods

title: Biden Approves Major Disaster Declaration in 7 Texas Counties After Deadly Storm
message:
Greg Abbott called for ‘robust action,’ citing ‘extensive damage caused by these severe storms, historic river flooding, and tornadoes.’President Joe Biden has approved a major disaster declaration in seven Texas counties affected by severe weather and flooding.
The mayor of Houston, which was hit hard by the storm, thanked President Biden for his “swift support” in approving the disaster declaration.
Downed power lines are shown in the aftermath of a severe thunderstorm, in Cypress, Texas, near Houston, on May 17, 2024.
(David J. Phillip/AP Photo)A man walks over fallen bricks from a damaged building in the aftermath of a severe thunderstorm, in Houston, Texas, on May 17, 2024.
Blown-out windows on a high-rise downtown building are shown in the aftermath of a severe thunderstorm in Houston, Texas, on May 17, 2024.

title: 4 . 7 Magnitude Earthquake Reported | The Patriot KEIB AM 1150
message:
A 4.7-magnitude earthquake struck Japan on Saturday (May 18), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The Tennessee earthquake struck days after a 3.8-magnitude earthquake struck Tennessee on Thursday (May 16), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The Tennessee earthquake struck hours after a 4.0-magnitude earthquake struck California on Wednesday (May 15), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The California earthquake struck hours after a 5.6-magnitude earthquake struck Puerto Rico on Tuesday (May 14), according to the United States Geological Survey.
The Puerto Rico earthquake was reported hours after a 5.1-magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia on Tuesday, according to the United States Geological Survey.

3. A 5.6-magnitude earthquake struck Puerto Rico on May 14, 2019 reported to United States Geological Survey.
4. A 5.1-magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia on May 14, 2019 it was reported to United States Geological Survey.

title: Hot weather poses new risk as thousands remain without power after deadly Houston storm
message:
Hot weather poses new risk as thousands remain without power after deadly Houston stormKaren Warren / Houston Chronicle via Associated PressHOUSTON — As the Houston area works to clean up and restore power to hundreds of thousands after deadly storms left at least seven people dead, it will do so amid a smog warning and scorching temperatures that could pose health risks.
“Don’t overdo yourself during the cleanup process,” the weather service’s Houston office said in a post on the social platform X.
In addition to the heat, the Houston area could face poor air quality during the weekend.
HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS REMAIN WITHOUT POWERThe widespread destruction of Thursday's storms brought much of Houston to a standstill.
School districts in the Houston area canceled classes Friday for more than 400,000 students and government offices were closed.
event_breakdown:

1. Deadly storms in Houston left at least seven people dead.
2. Freezing temperatures and a "bomb cyclone" are causing massive blackouts and many flights to be grounded.
3. In Texas, a weeklong winter storm generated the cold, snowy weather that hit the Houston-Baytown-Huntsville area.
4. Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said from 1 to 2 inches of rain was expected overnight at the coast with isolated totals of as much as 5 inches alsocould be causing related events and should be listed together

EducationAlberta Emergency AlertsFor up-to-the-minute Alberta Emergency Alert information visit: Alberta Emergency Alert.
Albertans are encouraged to download the Alberta Emergency Alert mobile app which immediately pushes all alerts out to subscribers.

title: Houston surveys destruction from deadly storms and races to restore power as Southeast and Gulf Coast face flood threat
message:
My condolences go out to the families that lost a loved one during yesterday’s severe weather event,” Gonzalez said.
The damaging storms will be followed by high temperatures in the 90s through the weekend and beyond while many are without air conditioning.
“Isolated to scattered severe thunderstorms appear possible across portions of the Southeast and Carolinas on Saturday, and parts of the Upper Midwest,” the center said.
The greatest chances for severe weather are across parts of Nebraska and Kansas, with a slight level 2 of 5 risk of severe thunderstorms issued by the Storm Prediction Center.
By the end of the weekend, thunderstorm chances will diminish for most of the Southeast and Mid-Atlantic, the weather service said.

title: BMKG prepares joint expedition to explore earthquake zones
message:
BMKG prepares joint expedition to explore earthquake zonesJakarta (ANTARA) - The Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) has begun preparing expeditions to investigate seismic phenomena in the megathrust zones in Indonesia, the agency's head, Dwikorita Karnawati, said on Sunday.The expeditions will be conducted by the BMKG and the National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN) for research and data collection.Karnawati said the expeditions will explore all megathrust zones in Indonesia: Sunda Subduction, Banda Subduction, Sulawesi Subduction, Philippine Sea Plate Subduction, Maluku Sea Plate Subduction, and North Papua Subduction.
"We've begun preparing everything, including research, training, and development centers, to create earthquake and tsunami models," she said.BMKG Head of Public Meteorology, Andri Ramdhani, said that the expeditions will begin in Batam, Riau Islands, and travel through several cities before reaching Bitung, North Sulawesi, on August 25.The research will involve a series of long voyages using OceanX's OceanXplorer ship.OceanX is a global non-profit organization in the field of marine exploration that collaborates with the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs and Investment to research Indonesian seas.The expeditions will not only investigate earthquake phenomena but also observe the interaction of air and sea in Indonesian waters.The target areas are where these interactions influence Indonesia's weather and climate variability, such as the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) and the ocean dipole in the Banda Sea.BMKG considers this research exploration crucial because natural and sometimes periodic changes in air and ocean circulation, volcanic eruptions, and other factors influence climate variability.Furthermore, only 19 percent of Indonesia's vast seas (over 70 percent of the country's area) have been mapped, highlighting the need for exploration, as Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment Luhut Binsar Pandjaitan stated in a recent coordination meeting.
"Preparations with OceanX are complete.
The BMKG is also bringing equipment to measure relevant parameters and continues coordination, especially with the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs and Investment as the leading sector," said Ramdhani.

title: Fresh floods kill 66 in northern Afghanistan : provincial official
message:
KABUL, May 19, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Fresh floods killed 66 people in Faryabprovince in northern Afghanistan, a provincial official said Sunday, in thelatest deadly flooding to hit the country.
Heavy floods in multiple districts of Faryab province on Saturday night"resulted in human and financial losses," Asmatullah Muradi, spokesman forthe Faryab governor, said in a statement.
"Due to the floods 66 people were killed," he said, adding that at least fivepeople were injured and others were still missing.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people werekilled in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Just over a week ago, more than 300 people were killed in flash flooding innorthern Baghlan province, according to the UN World Food Programme andTaliban officials.
event_breakdown: Floods in Faryab province, Afghanistan

title: At least 66 killed as fresh floods devastate northern Afghanistan
message:
At least 66 people were killed as fresh floods devastated northern Afghanistan's Faryab province, a provincial official said Sunday.
Hundreds of people have died in separate flash floods this month that have also swamped farmland in a country where 80% of the population depends on agriculture to survive.
"Due to the floods 66 people were killed," he said, adding that at least five people were injured and others were still missing.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people were killed in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Spring floods are not uncommon in Afghanistan, a country of more than 40 million people, but above-average rainfall this year has sparked devastating flash flooding.

2. Separately, hundreds of people were killed in separate flash floods this month in the country.

4. The floods came on a day after provincial police announced that more than 50 people were killed in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.

title: Thousands march in Cork town to demand flood protection measures
message:
Thousands have marched through a Cork town devastated by flooding last October to "scream out" for interim flood protection measures before the next storm season.
Organisers of the rally through Midleton in East Cork, the Midleton and East Cork Flood Protection Group, said they hope the event sends a clear message to government that they want and need urgent action over the coming months to protect homes, businesses and lives pending the delivery of the €50m Midleton flood relief scheme.
They need to start doing some of these interim works this summer.
In addition, Individual Property Protection (IPP) “is being considered” as part of the overall suite of measures for Midleton, the OPW said.
“A decision on this is expected shortly, so IPP can be rolled out by Cork County Council on a phased and targeted basis,” a spokesperson said.

.
1. Flooding East Cork
2. Flooding Midleton, East Cork (Irish town)

title: Boston artificial land vulnerable to climate change , harder to protect
message:
Artificial land is generally lower in elevation, and it cannot always hold as much weight as natural land without subsiding, Kunkel said.
That means the artificial land is both more vulnerable to sea level rise and more difficult to protect from flooding with heavy sea walls.
(Humanity still has time to reach net zero global emissions by 2050; if we do, sea level rise would likely be less.)
AdvertisementIn the 19th century, techniques changed; developers began to build stone sea walls and fill behind that point until it was above high tide.
Without that new berm in the park, 2 feet of sea level rise could bring flooding to Charlestown during an extreme storm.

title: Fresh floods kill 66 in northern Afghanistan
message:
Fresh floods kill 66 in northern AfghanistanKabul, May 19 (AFP) May 19, 2024Fresh floods killed 66 people in Faryab province in northern Afghanistan, a provincial official said Sunday, in the latest deadly flooding to hit the country.
Hundreds of people have died in separate flash floods this month that have also swamped farmland in a country where 80 percent of the population depends on agriculture to survive.

Afghan residents clean debris and salvage their belongings after flash floods following heavy rainfall at a damaged house in Firozkoh, Ghor province on May 18, 2024.

Heavy floods in multiple districts of Faryab province on Saturday night "resulted in human and financial losses," Asmatullah Muradi, spokesman for the Faryab governor, said in a statement.

title: Fresh floods kill 66 in northern Afghanistan
message:
Fresh floods killed 66 people in Faryab province in northern Afghanistan, a provincial official said Sunday, in the latest deadly flooding to hit the country.
Hundreds of people have died in separate flash floods this month that have also swamped farmland in a country where 80 percent of the population depends on agriculture to survive.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people were killed in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Residents in Baghlan, Ghor, Faryab and other affected regions found themselves without shelter, stripped of their homes and livelihoods.
Spring floods are not uncommon in Afghanistan, a country of more than 40 million people, but above-average rainfall this year has sparked devastating flash flooding.
event_breakdown: Flash flooding- Afghanistan

title: At least 66 dead as new floods hit Afghanistan Faryab province | Floods News
message:
Fresh floods have killed at least 66 people in Faryab province in northern Afghanistan, says a provincial official, in the latest deadly string of disasters to hit the country in recent days.
Heavy floods in multiple districts of Faryab province on Saturday night “resulted in human and financial losses”, Asmatullah Moradi, spokesman for the Faryab governor, said in a statement on Sunday.
“Due to the floods 66 people were killed,” he said, adding that at least five people were injured and several others missing.
Another 18 people had also died in floods in the same province on Friday, Moradi added.
The latest disaster in Faryab came just a day after provincial authorities said 50 people were killed in flash flooding just south of the province in Ghor.
event_breakdown:
- Heavy flooding killed at least 50 people in Ghor province in Afghanistan.

title: How  kitty cat are wrecking the home insurance industry
message:
The rising cost of homeowner’s insurance is now one of the most prominent symptoms of climate change in the United States.
Losses from severe convective storms increased by about 9 percent every year between 1989 and 2022, according to the insurance firm Aon.
But climate change may also be playing a role: Convective storms tend to form in hot, moist, and unstable weather conditions.
Even large “reinsurers,” which sell insurance to insurance companies around the world, are feeling the sting from these storms.
But the increasing trend of “attritional” losses from repeated convective storms does threaten to cut into their profit margins.
event_breakdown: Severe convective storms, large reinsurers
